Ashley Vogel
Mar 28

Taking the Lane: On Bikes, Health(care), and Feminism

This time of year is loaded with emotions for me. On Saint Patrick’s Day three years ago, I ended up in the ER at HUP, sharing the space with several Penn students who were suffering from alcohol poisoning. I was there for very different reasons. I had recently been diagnosed with stage 4 cancer and was waiting for treatment to start. My body disagreed with the date my doctor had chosen to start chemotherapy. I was trying to go about life as normal, which was an impossible task: I felt like I was dying, my body was feeling the effects of the giant tumor in my chest pressing on my heart and lungs, and I was in such terrible pain that I could not sleep through the night. At 2 A.M., I woke up my housemates and they called an Uber, escorting me to the emergency room. We watched terrible television in between me going in for tests, and at 7 A.M. I got a call from my oncologist, who pushed my chemo up to that morning.

If you saw me on the streets today, you would never guess this happened to me three years ago. I now have long, lustrous hair. I look like a pretty typical twenty-six year old, except maybe I have a few extra tattoos, piercings, and pairs of Docs. I am in a running group, and I ride my bike everyday.

I credit my bicycle with a lot more than your average bike commuter likely does. I work at a bike advocacy organization, and yet I feel I don’t hear enough times in a day how powerful this old technology is.

I don’t want to reinforce the image of all cancer survivors being like Lance Armstrong, but cycling is physically powerful. Having been so sick I could barely walk a city block or a staircase when I was diagnosed, and then being weakened by the chemo itself, I fantasized about running marathons and being a triathlete while I was in treatment. Buying a bike seemed like a good first step in becoming the physically strong badass I wished to be post-chemo. I picked one out during my last weeks of treatment (and did some test rides, which was probably a bad idea since my immune system took a beating from chemo and my counts were always low), and I picked it up directly before my last chemo appointment. I thought because I had already faced my biggest fear that riding in city traffic, a prospect that had terrified me before, would be no big deal. I was wrong. When I first stepped off the sidewalk and pedaled on the streets of South Philly, I was extremely intimidated. This was what I had dreamed of, however, so my anxiety was also tinged with excitement. I explained my apparent trepidation to a male passerby, who mansplained that I should be riding on the sidewalk [FALSE]. He also made fun of my new bike, a beautiful Breezer that my bike mechanic friend helped me choose. Finally, he corrected my language when I said I was new to biking; I was “cycling,” not “biking.”

At this point I really felt like I didn’t know what I was doing, but somehow I continued onto Washington Avenue. I was filled with fear but also a rush hit me. Luckily I found a more supportive community in Women Bike PHL* than in that guy who gave me pointers on my first time out. With this support, I grew comfortable in exploring many parts of the city by bike. I would feel particularly strong when I traversed a bridge into West Philly and made it over some of the neighborhood’s hills. It was always an emotional experience (and remains one to this day) when I would bike along Spruce and pass HUP and the rest of Penn’s medical complex. I race past with an extra expenditure of energy, glancing at the place where I received twelve infusions of a cocktail of extremely harsh drugs at age twenty-three, a place where I was convinced I would die when I received my diagnosis.

Riding my bike is a daily exercise of gratitude for my strong body and a reminder of its resilient nature. Cycling made me feel strong again after going through an experience that made me feel weak beyond repair, and it continues to make me feel strong. But it is more than physically empowering. What I appreciate most about riding my bike, especially in the city, is that it has taught me how to ask for what I need. I ride through South Philly everyday, where it is necessary for me to take the lane to stay safe. This practice has been more empowering than anything else. Taking up space is definitely not something I was socialized to do as a woman. I suffered many months at the hands of doctors who dismissed my symptoms as stress and anxiety. I could have benefitted from a lesson in advocating for my rights and taking up space in a system that was set up to dismiss my concerns. I have finally learned that lesson from getting on the road everyday and insisting on being given the space I need to stay safe. I travel through the rest of my life with an increased confidence, “taking the lane” in areas other than my morning commute.

While I get a rush from riding out in traffic and a sense of empowerment from traveling in a way that signals to other road users that I have a right to the space, I also wish to see a city where cyclists rights’ and safety are a given. Fighting for them has been good practice in self-advocacy, but I would like to see respect for my livelihood and wellbeing (and that of other cyclists) centered in the way people use the road. After all, I endured all that chemo because I want to live.

*Women Bike PHL is an initiative of the Bicycle Coalition of Greater Philadelphia that aims to shrink the gender gap in bicycling, making riding a bicycle more fun and feasible for Philadelphia women of all ages and backgrounds. You can join the Facebook group here: https://www.facebook.com/groups/womenbikephl/
